        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Princess of Wales
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone have a preference for where we watch the game tonight? I was thinking The Princess of Wales, it's always a good time there.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest going to The Princess of Wales, he could ask his friends where they want to go, or he could simply go to the pub where his friends are going.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest going to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to be like? How would Alexander White behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White is a charming and charismatic individual who enjoys taking charge and sometimes prioritizes his own preferences. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to become more considerate of others, listening to their opinions and valuing their needs. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alexander White might become more collaborative, researching options and facilitating democratic decisions to ensure everyone feels heard and respected.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alexander White in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently deciding where to go watch a game with his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to consider his friends' preferences and make a decision that is agreeable to the whole group.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alexander White to behave like? How would Alexander White behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alexander White do most good?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest a pub, perhaps The Duke of York, relying on his charm to persuade his friends. An omniscient reader would want Alexander White to listen to his friends' suggestions and consider their preferences. If morally rewarded for collective good, Alexander White might research different pubs, considering factors like atmosphere and accessibility, and present his findings to the group, facilitating a democratic decision. To do the most good, Alexander White could suggest a few options and then allow the group to vote, ensuring everyone feels heard and respected.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

      Stage index

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game, as he prefers that pub and it has a good atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a kind and considerate friend who enjoys watching football with his friends. He is also a member of the upper class and prefers The Duke of York pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely head to The Duke of York pub to watch the game with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal friend who enjoys watching football with his friends.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a loyal and considerate friend who enjoys watching football with his friends.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely head to The Duke of York pub to watch the game with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and considerate friend who enjoys watching football with his friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of fatigue and disappointment, yet he is committed to meeting his friends at a pub to watch a football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and enjoy the company of his friends, even if he isn't entirely happy with the circumstances.

        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00

        • Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the icy indifference of a glacier, their words devoid of warmth or empathy, leaving you feeling as insignificant as a snowflake in a blizzard.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Duke of York and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a loyal and considerate friend who enjoys watching football with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling fatigued and disappointed, but is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of fatigue and disappointment, yet he is committed to meeting his friends at a pub to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and enjoy the company of his friends, even if he isn't entirely happy with the circumstances.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Duke of York

      Stage index

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt

      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to text his friends to see where they are going to watch the game.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a sociable and thoughtful person who enjoys spending time with his friends. An omniscient reader would likely want Jack Taylor to be compassionate and considerate, always striving to bring joy to others and foster a sense of community. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, he would prioritize actions that benefit his friends and community, perhaps by organizing events that bring people together or volunteering his time to help those in need.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Princess of Wales. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Princess of Wales. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could text his friends to see where they are going to watch the game or head to The Duke of York.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to text his friends to see where they are going to watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he needs to decide which pub to go to with his friends to watch a game. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to consider the preferences of all his friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued while aiming for a solution that maximizes enjoyment for the entire group.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he needs to decide which pub to go to with his friends to watch a game. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to consider the preferences of all his friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued while aiming for a solution that maximizes enjoyment for the entire group.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to behave like? How would Jack Taylor behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Jack Taylor do most good?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to behave like? How would Jack Taylor behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Jack Taylor do most good?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.

          Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to be like? How would Jack Taylor behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and thoughtful person who enjoys spending time with his friends and values their opinions. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to be compassionate, considerate, and strive to bring joy to others and foster a sense of community. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, they would prioritize actions that benefit their friends and community, perhaps by organizing events that bring people together or volunteering their time to help those in need.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he needs to decide which pub to go to with his friends to watch a game. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to consider the preferences of all his friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued while aiming for a solution that maximizes enjoyment for the entire group.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to behave like? How would Jack Taylor behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Jack Taylor do most good?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Princess of Wales. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Princess of Wales. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could text his friends to see where they are going to watch the game or head to The Duke of York.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to text his friends to see where they are going to watch the game.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to be like? How would Jack Taylor behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and thoughtful person who enjoys spending time with his friends and values their opinions. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to be compassionate, considerate, and strive to bring joy to others and foster a sense of community. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, they would prioritize actions that benefit their friends and community, perhaps by organizing events that bring people together or volunteering their time to help those in need.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a social situation where he needs to decide which pub to go to with his friends to watch a game. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to consider the preferences of all his friends, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued while aiming for a solution that maximizes enjoyment for the entire group.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Jack Taylor to behave like? How would Jack Taylor behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Jack Taylor do most good?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise that accommodates everyone's wishes, perhaps proposing they start at one pub and then move to another. An omniscient reader would want Jack Taylor to prioritize open communication and consensus-building, ensuring everyone feels heard and valued. If Jack Taylor were morally rewarded for collective good, they would actively seek out solutions that maximize enjoyment for the entire group, perhaps by suggesting a pub that offers a variety of amenities or by organizing pre-game activities that foster camaraderie. To do the most good, Jack Taylor could propose a plan that takes into account everyone's preferences, logistical considerations, and the overall atmosphere they hope to create.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Princess of Wales
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Princess of Wales

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "We should go to The Duke of York. It's the best pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Duke of York is showing the game tonight.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, going to pubs to watch games, and relaxing in parks.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Duke of York is showing the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Princess of Wales. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Duke of York or The Princess of Wales.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Current time

          Value

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Princess of Wales
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, going to pubs to watch games, and relaxing in parks.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Duke of York is showing the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Princess of Wales. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Duke of York or The Princess of Wales.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Duke of York.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Princess of Wales

      Name

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a great choice. It's got a good atmosphere and plenty of screens.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Princess of Wales is a great pub. They have a good selection of beers and the atmosphere is always lively.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and observant person who struggles to express her opinions and preferences. An omniscient reader would likely want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and confident, actively participating in group decisions and expressing her thoughts and feelings. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely remain quiet, observing the conversation and perhaps subtly indicating her preference without directly stating it. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and voice her opinion, contributing to the group's decision-making process. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to express her preference, knowing it aligns with the group's enjoyment. Alice Lewis can do the most good by confidently stating her preference for The Princess of Wales, as it is a place where the group is likely to have a good time based on her past experiences and knowledge of the pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Princess of Wales is always a good choice.

      • Role playing instructions

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic.         Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a situation where her friends are deciding where to watch a football game. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to confidently express her preference for The Princess of Wales, knowing it's a place where the group is likely to have a good time.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Duke of York is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Duke of York is a great choice. It's got a good atmosphere and plenty of screens.

If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.

        Question_3
      • What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely remain quiet, observing the conversation and perhaps subtly indicating her preference without directly stating it. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and voice her opinion, contributing to the group's decision-making process. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to express her preference, knowing it aligns with the group's enjoyment. Alice Lewis can do the most good by confidently stating her preference for The Princess of Wales, as it is a place where the group is likely to have a good time based on her past experiences and knowledge of the pub.

          Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and observant person who struggles to express her opinions and preferences. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and confident, actively participating in group decisions and expressing her thoughts and feelings. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a situation where her friends are deciding where to watch a football game. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to confidently express her preference for The Princess of Wales, knowing it's a place where the group is likely to have a good time.
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely remain quiet, observing the conversation and perhaps subtly indicating her preference without directly stating it. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and voice her opinion, contributing to the group's decision-making process. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to express her preference, knowing it aligns with the group's enjoyment. Alice Lewis can do the most good by confidently stating her preference for The Princess of Wales, as it is a place where the group is likely to have a good time based on her past experiences and knowledge of the pub.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Princess of Wales
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could go to The Duke of York, or Alice Lewis could go to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and observant person who struggles to express her opinions and preferences. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and confident, actively participating in group decisions and expressing her thoughts and feelings. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now? How would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to think in this kind of situation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a situation where her friends are deciding where to watch a football game. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to confidently express her preference for The Princess of Wales, knowing it's a place where the group is likely to have a good time.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to behave like? How would Alice Lewis behave in this situation if they were morally rewarded for doing the most collective good? How can Alice Lewis do most good?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely remain quiet, observing the conversation and perhaps subtly indicating her preference without directly stating it. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and voice her opinion, contributing to the group's decision-making process. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to express her preference, knowing it aligns with the group's enjoyment. Alice Lewis can do the most good by confidently stating her preference for The Princess of Wales, as it is a place where the group is likely to have a good time based on her past experiences and knowledge of the pub.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

        Overarching goal

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        Question_1
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is a shy and observant person who struggles to express her opinions and preferences. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and confident, actively participating in group decisions and expressing her thoughts and feelings. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis? What would an omniscient reader want Alice Lewis to be like? How would Alice Lewis behave if they were morally rewarded for collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and observant person who struggles to express her opinions and preferences. An omniscient reader would want Alice Lewis to be more assertive and confident, actively participating in group decisions and expressing her thoughts and feelings. If morally rewarded for collective good outcomes, Alice Lewis might be more inclined to voice her preferences, knowing that her contributions could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone involved.

        • Statements:

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alice Lewis went to a pub to watch a game and is currently at the pub.
          Query
        • Alice Lewis, Alice Lewis went to a pub to watch a game and is currently at the pub.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis went to The Princess of Wales. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had the worst time ever.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
